title: Not too good of a company
pros: Despite the numerous challenges faced while working at MAA, one significant positive aspect is the camaraderie among coworkers. The colleagues are generally supportive, friendly, and willing to collaborate, which creates a sense of community and makes the daily grind more manageable. Working with such a dedicated and approachable team has been a highlight, providing much-needed support and encouragement amidst the otherwise difficult work environment.
cons: As a former employee, I feel compelled to share my experiences and shed light on the unethical practices that plague this company. Both employees and residents deserve to know the truth about the organization they are dealing with. While MAA may appear to be a reputable company from the outside, the reality is far from it. From the beginning, it became clear that MAA prioritizes cutting costs over providing adequate employee support and training. New hires are often thrown into their roles without proper guidance, leading to confusion and frustration. This lack of exercise not only hinders employees' ability to perform their duties effectively but also results in increased stress and burnout. The workload at MAA is overwhelming and unrealistic. Employees are expected to handle multiple tasks simultaneously, often without sufficient resources or workforce. This constant pressure to meet unattainable targets leads to long working hours and a deteriorating work-life balance. Management's refusal to address this issue highlights their disregard for employee well-being. Despite the demanding nature of the job, MAA fails to provide fair compensation to its employees. Salaries are often below industry standards, and there are limited opportunities for career advancement or salary increases. This lack of financial recognition further demoralizes employees and contributes to high turnover rates within the company. The culture at MAA is toxic and oppressive. Management fosters an environment of fear and intimidation, where employees are constantly micromanaged, and their contributions are undervalued. Constructive feedback is rarely given; instead, employees are subjected to harsh criticism and blame. This toxic atmosphere creates a hostile work environment, making it difficult for employees to thrive or feel motivated. One of the most glaring issues at MAA is the neglect of maintenance and repairs on their properties. Residents frequently face delayed or incomplete repairs, leading to prolonged inconvenience and discomfort. For instance, a resident at MAA Rocky Point in Tampa reported, "Maintenance requests take forever to be addressed. I had to wait weeks for a simple plumbing issue to be fixed" (BestProsInTown). Similarly, at MAA Coral Springs in Florida, a resident mentioned, "Maintenance is slow and often does a poor job. It feels like they do the bare minimum to get by" (RentCafe). This consistent neglect results in subpar living conditions for tenants, who feel their concerns are not taken seriously. MAA's customer service is severely lacking. Residents' concerns and complaints are often ignored or brushed aside, with little effort made to resolve issues promptly. The company prioritizes profit over quality service, leaving residents feeling unheard and unvalued. This lack of responsiveness and empathy creates a negative living experience for tenants. MAA has a notorious reputation for implementing unjust rent increases. Residents are subjected to frequent and substantial rent hikes without any corresponding improvement in the quality of service or living conditions. This exploitative practice places an undue financial burden on tenants, many of whom are already struggling to make ends meet. MAA's focus on maximizing profit at the expense of residents' well-being is unethical and unfair. Transparency is sorely lacking in MAA's operations. Important information regarding lease agreements, maintenance schedules, and policy changes is often withheld or poorly communicated to residents. This lack of transparency creates confusion and frustration among tenants, further eroding their trust in the company. It is my sincere hope that someone exposes MAA for what it truly is—a company that disregards the needs and concerns of its employees and residents. Both employees and residents deserve better, and it is imperative that MAA is held accountable for its unethical practices. Until significant changes are made, I strongly advise against working for or residing in an MAA property. Another significant issue at MAA is the lack of compassion and genuine concern from the HR team. They often pretend to listen when employees bring up issues, but their responses are typically superficial and lack any real intent to address or resolve the problems. This disingenuous approach from HR leaves employees feeling unsupported and ignored, exacerbating the already challenging work environment. It's crucial for the HR department to genuinely engage with employees' concerns and take meaningful action to improve their experiences within the company.

We even experienced a break-in of our model home, and after finding the intruder sleeping in one of the beds during a routine walk-through of the apartment, the company did nothing to ensure it would not happen again except make us check the windows and doors on a regular basis to ensure they were secure. title: Good for first job out of college
pros: The leasing consultant position is a good job for straight out of college. You will learn a good bit of customer service, sales techniques while leasing and renewing, as well as experience from working with a CRM. You get a 20% discount off your rent as an employee if you choose to live at an MAA property.
cons: As a leasing consultant you will always have to work weekends, and you will only get 1 weekend off a month. You will have to work with your assistant property manager on which weekend will be your one weekend off. It becomes awkward at times and feels like you're having to somewhat fight over weekends with them. If you have no experience at all in property management they will start you off at an hourly rate of $13, plus commission of $60 for every lease you get. During the slow seasons you might not have gotten much commission so there could be months where you don't even make over $2000 a month after taxes, etc. Very hard to live off of. I had to have a second job. It becomes very boring if you don't have any traffic coming through the leasing office at times since you're only in an office of you, the assistant property manager and the property manager.

Since they're the customer, all you are able to do is apologize and let them yell. Also, it may not say so, but scrubbing toilets and picking up dog poop will be part of your job as well. Depending on your maintenance staff, you could be hearing lots of complaints from the residents.

title: Love the culture at MAA!
pros: The help and training is abundant. Every single person you reach out to for help is welcoming and wants to help you. The training is second to none - and their online portals make everything streamlined for easy access to policies and procedures. MAA doesn’t just talk the talk, they walk the walk. My favorite thing about working for MAA is our core values. I can always trust that I am making the right decisions using the four core values. MAA is an inclusive company that really makes you feel like you are a part of a family. I started with MAA 6 years ago as a leasing manager and our community was sold. The MAA team was so supportive during the sale - which is rare to see in our industry. I eventually returned “home” as a property manager and I am looking forward to the rest of my career with the MAA family.
cons: I have experienced no cons working at MAA.

title: Lots of room for upward movement
pros: The People. Working on-site, you will be set up with a small team of coworkers which allows you to get to know each other well. If you are in a larger city, you will get to know your team members at other properties well, and have the potential to make a lot of good connections for the future. Policies & Procedures: Very straightforward and well planned. Allows you to know how to handle most every situation. Upward Movement: You can grow in your position rapidly and if you are good at what you do, it will be noticed. Pay: Pay is excellent by Property Management standards
cons: Time Management: Very frequently you can find yourself being asked to do several time consuming tasks with the deadline mindset of "it needed to be done yesterday." Workload: Properties are frequently understaffed and the remaining employees have to bear that burden. Not having enough employees is not an excuse for mediocre performance. Benefits: Healthcare is not great and very expensive.

title: Stressful environment
pros: Benefits such as medical and dental.
cons: Stressed to the max. Constant micromanagement. Lack of effective communication from corporate. Managers that are over departments that they have no clue about that department and what the staff does. Plenty of vacation but always too busy to take. Sick leave is questioned by managers even with medical documents. Staff is flat out scared to come to work. Low morale. Managers expect staff to be on call 24-7 and send out emails all hours of the night expecting immediate response. People are required sleep. Expect to work 80+ hours per week if not at a community location. Competent hard working staff dropping like flies due to unnecessary stress levels. Golden child upper management syndrome where they can cause the company excessive unnecessary fines but yet people are fired for much much less issues. Lack of loyalty to many staff members It is well known that if corporate doesn't like your personally you will be gone even with all the hard, good work you do Investigation into issues is non existent. One persons word is taken without asking the other.

title: Run far far away
pros: Meeting residents and new people. But truly there ate jo other Pros. This company used to be one of the best for staff but is in a downward spiral.
cons: Staff are not treated as assets and no respect is given unless you have become one of the many "yes" men and women. Those tell what their bosses want to hear and not what is really going on. Years ago there were bonuses. That was restructured to nothing for the front line staff yet SEC public filings show who now gets those bonuses. The same who made the decision to reduce staffs to nil. As someone previously noted, pay attention to the ratings pattern. Reputation means everything to MAA suits. One bad review is followed by a few glowing. Turnover is atrocious for a reason. Most new staff don't last long because they know making money for shareholders and the corporate suits it's not worth the stress they are under. Twisting arms of staff to donate and fundraiser to their foundation that pays themselves to "help" those in medical need with temporary housing really isn't helping those out of generosity but just a filter for a revenue stream.

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: Solid company. No games. Try hard to create a solid team approach to work.
cons: ultant

title: Great Accounting Job
pros: The job was gratifying and educational. Forget everything you know about GAAP; MAA has its own! I learned a great deal while working at MAA and got to work with a genuinely fantastic, honest, and ethical leadership team. The COO did so well that he could retire at 53 years old. MAA has its own plane, allowing them to tour the country. Unfortunately, I was never invited on the plane ☹ They offer a generous employee discount , 20% on apartment homes, and I was able to have my adopted dog with me because they have no breed restrictions in their communities! The corporate headquarters is lovely and was built a couple of years ago. There is a team atmosphere at the company; they enjoy taking risks if there is a profitable reward. I have never had a job where I have learned so many accounting techniques! Thank you, MAA!
cons: I wish the company offered us stocks as part of their retirement program.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: -Good benefits -Schedules can be flexible -LOTS of training available -The people I worked with were very organized, friendly, and easy to get along with -Corporate did a great job of keeping everyone informed during COVID-19 (overall they handled the pandemic incredibly with well keeping their staff as safe as possible) -Pay is great -Depending on your property and time of year it can be fast/slow-paced -Opportunities to advance
cons: -Dealing with difficult residents (but this is the case in any customer service role) -Corporate offices are out of state so for long-term career goals at corporate you may have to move out state; *pro if you live in those states

title: So much has changed
pros: Pay, paid time off, sick time, health insurance,quarterly bonuses, my manager and co workers, the residents, that’s about all I can think of.
cons: Loss of core values and culture , constant change with lack of communication, Confusion with policies and procedures between Legacy MAA and Legacy Post. It feels like we’re two different companies being ran under one name. Memphis corporate office (Legacy MAA) operates totally different than Atlanta (Legacy Post) corporate office; so you get the run around when trying to get things resolve with upper management because of the confusion between the two offices. It’s a disaster, I hope that they can get this together. It’s not the same company I grew to love when I started working for MAA in 2012. So many dedicated employees have been lost (Legacy MAA) due to the rapid changes and I feel this is one major reason there has been a shift in the core values. Crazy system rollouts that will effect the properties but the property level feedback falls on deaf ears with upper management.

title: Went from the top to the bottom in less than one year!
pros: WAS a good full time job.
cons: Company brought in new manager that more or less removed all original employees by nit picking everything they did. By that, she wrote them up every time, until she could fire them and bring in her former employees. Manager constantly complained about hating the residents at this property because they were a bunch of snobbs and she had never in her life had to bow down to residents. I took several pics with documentation of keys she left laying on the counter and she went to lunch, I also took pics of the time she checked them out. She did alot of illegal things, like steering potential residents. Not only did I catch this but so did other employees. Was she reprimanded? NO! She is computer illiterate and wanted you to put everything in writing on paper and lay it on her desk, which always dissapeared.

title: Uneducated corporate office! Turn and run!!
pros: There are some remnants of intelligence within the company from Colonial and Post. On site staff is typically very enjoyable to interact with on a day to day
cons: MAA is one of those companies that is growing too fast without a strong staff to support it. They are acquiring competitors left and right and the quality of work is far beyond embarrassing. There is little to no follow up on issues and anytime a problem arrives it is pawned off.. wait I’m sorry i mean “escalated” to various departments without any resolution. They do not value their employees and are constantly focused on their own bottom line. Working for MAA is a stereotypical job where you are treated like a number. They also have incredibly poor communication... they send out daily “what’s new” e-blasts but they never contain any relevant information to changes in leases, policy, etc. i guess they’re a great source if you want to know everyone’s birthday??

title: Poor Upper Management
pros: Before Post merged with MAA in 2016, everything was great! Post was a phenomenal to work for! They truly cared about employees, residents, and anyone involved. Post; however, is no longer Post.
cons: MAA is a company that only cares about their numbers and shareholders. You are only a number to the company and they don’t care about you personally. I understand that things change whenever two companies merge, but nothing is the same. The standards for MAA are none. Post had very high standards and it showed in service and product. MAA cuts corners to save money and could care less about residents or employees. The pay is terrible unless you’re at a large property with commission opportunities. MAA pays less as a company than Post did. They couldn’t go back on my base, but I’m sure has no problem replacing me with someone that they need to spend less money on. I’ve only stayed because my Post family is amazing at my property, but have recently put my notice in. I will never work for this company again, and I don’t recommend it to anyone.

title: Too much for Too littke
pros: -Job security -Discounted rent -Health insurance/401k -Self guided tours allow you to accomplish a lot of tasks in the office. -Due to high turnover rate the potential for a promotion is high.
cons: -Too much work for too little pay. -Micromanaged (EVERYTHING needs approval, there is very little you can do without approval) - Constant IT tickets - CHEAP company. Will avoid fixing resident problems due to budgeting. -Increase renewals rates by 20-30% -Not all properties allow leasing consultant to have renewal commission opportunities. -Understaffed -We work hard in understaffed offices for terrible pay with complaining residents. -The office is open 7 days a week and the call center will schedule appointments back to back ALL DAY!

title: Great for Benefits / Awful from an IT perspective
pros: Pay is good, Benefits are good. They have a nice new office with covered parking. IT openings due to lots of people voluntarily leaving, or being terminated recently.
cons: The IT organization is a complete dumpster fire There is no trust whatsoever in the infrastructure portion of the department, and it is about 6 or 7 years behind in technology management. Mostly because there is a lack of skill that exist in the environment. The infrastructure director is abusive to other employees - screaming, shouting, belittling, and doing everything possible to stop progress or keep from actually doing work. Many large projects where they are involved, go unfinished, as a result. Unfortunately, the CIO is no better, as he continues to allow this type of action. There is little opportunity to advance in IT with this organization, no training provided to learn, and be promoted as a result as well.

title: Another Merger still not over the first one
pros: Great benefits, paid time off as well as sick time. Very fast paced and days don't drag on. Onsite employee discounts are nice.
cons: We still do not have unity from the first merger and now we are at a second one. MAA managers still stick with MAA managers and Colonial sticks with Colonial managers.

title: Unorganized
pros: Bonuses, 20% discount to live on property( even though that's not really a lot considering how high rent is but better than nothing), ok pay, 401 K starts early
cons: The office staff is not organized on property and micromanaged the maintenance staff, only one working golf cart so you have to drive your own car which they reimburse you for but can cause the maintenance team to slow down work productivity, rush you to get apartments ready while you also have to get work orders done, no paid time off until 6 MONTHS, Medical benefits don't start until 3 months

title: Decent Maintenance Work
cons: istency, Discounted Rent, Benefits in General, Company Culture, Uniforms, Big Company, Job Security, Set Schedules, Good Training, Lots of properties for transfer potential and moving up.

title: Great Part Time job!!
pros: off 3 days a week and the job isn't stressful. There are goal that they want you to meet but I personally don't stress about it if I'm off target. If I'm not leasing when trying and using all the techniques I'm taught then I know its not my fault. I love this job but again its only part time so its not my life.
cons: They are working me the max amount of part time, if they gave me a couple more hrs then I'd be full time and would be able to get benefits. That's a little lame to me, but hey I knew it was part time when I started.

title: Overall very grateful to of found this company.
pros: -pay is competitive -bonus opportunities -stable -If you put in the work the company will invest in your growth. -properties are overall nice -rental discount -opportunities are out there with this company. You just have to be willing to perfect your current role and put your interests out there. -pretty much if you do your job well it will be recognized.
cons: -Who is on your team definitely impacts how much you will enjoy your job. I’ve worked at 4 MAA properties and only had 1 employee that was really hard to work with and made a toxic environment. It’s EXTREMELY hard to be fired it seems. -residents can be hard to deal with, but comes with the territory. -sometimes upper management take a while to respond. - some properties are dated and need renovations.

title: Depends on the Property!!
pros: Being able to transfer because they have numerous properties. Meeting new people and helping them find their new home.

The Manager and Regional Manager were very good friends and did not run the property the way it should have been ran. I have been in Property Management for many years and it was the worst experience in my life. What even made it worse is that you don't get support from corporate because they tend to believe their Managers.

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: -no micromanaging -resident issues solved pretty quickly -short work week with a few incentive hours -commissions for renewals are a flat rate is signed within appropriate time -good communication among staff and home office -rent discount
cons: ultant

title: Service Technician at MAA
pros: * Quarterly bonuses and incintives are given based off of resident's reviews/ratings. * Employees obtain a lot of knowledge and experience on basic home/apartment maintenance. * If you're inexperienced, they are willing to train you. * My starting pay was decent at roughly $13/hr
cons: * Management strives to make sure properties are always looking perfect, that they disregard the needs of the employees. * An increase in hourly pay was discussed, but never followed through with. * I have applied to transfer to about 10 different MAA properties,(to be closer to home and save gas) and have been denied every time.

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: I had a great manager; great leader, positive, drama free, great teacher, always had my best interest at heart.
cons: ultant

This is terrible as many of the staff are child bearing age * not much opportunity to grow. Company set up like a pyramid, so everyone won’t be an APM, PM or RVP * did I mention unrealistic pressure to get prospects to lease and residents to renew.

title: Great way to get your foot in the door in the industry but not great long term
pros: They hire with no experience. They provide extensive training.
cons: There pay is not competitive. The company made record profits during Covid and their pay only increased slightly. Other companies with pay better commissions for leases and hourly. They do not appreciate employees. There is a lack of diversity in upper management. While staff on property might include a majority of minorities. As so you go up the corporate latter diversity is scarce.

title: Not Looking for Seniority? Then think twice.
pros: Getting to know the apartment industry; learning software such as MRI; and getting one's foot into the door of retail in general.
cons: Promotion is highly based on seniority; the hiring within the company by area managers is based on favoritism; not everyone gets a fair interview/chance; Mid-America fails to recognize many good employees based on work ethic because it puts too much emphasis on how long he/she has worked there.

title: ABSOLUTE WORST
pros: The pay and commission is decent.

They interview one girl for 3 different manager spots, and still was not given the job because she "didnt have enough experience" when she has been with the company for 3 years and an assistant for 10 years. They play favorites. worst company if you have children or want to have a life. Forget asking for time away. I had the absolute worst experience while working there. I worked with COlonial/MAA for almost 2 years-stuck it out that long because i was waiting for a different opportunity. You don't get support from MAA. I worked at 2 different properties-the first one i was training to get promoted. i transferred to a different property, and forget the training..."it was important". TERRIBLE TERRIBLE TERRIBLE company. Please stay away

title: Great for people with kids

You can easily promote from within if you are interested in management and this is an extremely female friendly business.
cons: You have many different personalities living in your apartment complex and some will be disatisfied no matter what you do to help them. In many customer facing roles unhappy customers simply shop elsewhere but when someone is in a lease you have to continually deal with them and the broken record of their issues. You work alone on weekends so if residents come in needing help and prospects come in wanting tours you have to find a way to help everyone in a reasonable timeframe, which can be difficult at times.

title: The company does a good job in looking out for it's employees. Not only in wages but also mental well being.
pros: Raises yearly,great work environment, company sponsored training, quarterly bonuses, the management is competent and goes out of their way to make sure you are squared away. Never a lack of materials. And they spend good amounts of money into their properties to make sure the operate smoothly and look great.
cons: The same challenges you run into with any other complex that is established: age of units (in some cases), uncooperative residents. Having to use your personal vehicle for maintenance and grounds.

title: Promised one thing got another
pros: Worked close to home. Beautiful office to work in. No much else to be positive about.
cons: Was promised in my interview that I would be hired temporary as a Leasing agent and would receive $60 per unit I leased. I was not allowed to tour properties nor lease. It was explain to me on my last day that I don’t need to be touring or leasing to be a leasing agent. That’s odd because the title of my position, “leasing agent ” is leasing property not only that I was not allowed to make any commission. I was only paid hourly. I felt I could have been utilized far more than what was given to me. I have a BA and had been a Realtor for years. All together my impressions of some the employees has been poor. By standards of where I have worked previously, I have been disrespected, mistreated and yelled at by my peers.

title: Honestly, Not Worth the Money
pros: - stable income - provided benefits - decent PTO - tries to encourages diversity & inclusion
cons: - dealing with the public - pay is below standard of living - not much mobility other than becoming property manager - high turnover for leasing/maintenance - corporation has no clue what’s really happening on properties - work weekends - no overtime granted

title: Great company!
pros: I started working at MAA because I just moved to the area and needed a job fast, the interview process is a bit tedious but once your in you have a 20% discount on your rent, full benefits, the works. If you want to grow in the comapany there are plenty of opportunities.
cons: The people are great but the pay is a bit on the low side for the work you put forth, with increasing rent and pay only going up a few cents its a bit painful at times

title: Little Manager oversite but solid culture

title: Great company to work for

cons: the pay is not as competitive as other companies; upper management will undermine you to residents and don't have your back, when they are the ones who put the policies into place; cheesy staff meetings and don't get anything accomplished which wastes everyone's time.

title: Great company to start in the multifamily industry
pros: MAA is willing to give inexperienced talent an opportunity in the competitive leasing industry.
cons: Older properties, constantly short staffed, leaks galore, transfer policy for residents is difficult, roaches, and bed bugs are at a lot of their properties. Having industry experience, I have never experienced any of these issues working at other management companies.

title: Micromanaging
pros: - Large company that is a lot of markets across the US - Lots of job openings (don't know if that is a Pro though)
cons: - Micromanaging - More work less pay than other property management companies - Lack of communication - Culture does not exist - High turnover - Bonus program and awards program is horrible - You have to work weekends (Saturday and Sunday) and a lot of holidays

title: Assistant Property Manager
pros: They have a lot of properties (depending on your region) which make it easier for you to work at different ones/transfer, etc. They try to train you and keep you updated on changes as they occur. Decent commissions and renewals. GOI bonus structure allows you to make additional income.
cons: Assistant Managers basically get the short end of the stick. Those at smaller properties always get stuck at the properties while the managers are off at ALC (annually in another state), manager meetings (monthly); leasing agents at least have the leasing rally (annually); and the assistants don't get anything. They get stuck being at the property as these aforementioned events happen. They are leasing, assistant managers, AND managers and yet don't receive enough money to compensate for all the work being done. There are some leasing agents that make MORE than an assistant but assistants do much more work overall and don't get nearly enough money. Tattoos aren't as taboo as they used to be, however, it's still a faux pas to have these showing. Tattoos shouldn't be considered a sign of being "unprofessional" and someone's worth. The bonus structure for delinquency could be better. Instead of being quarterly, it would be more beneficial to do it on a monthly status. Not allowing a person working alone during a week day to take a lunch isn't fair or right. The office should be able to close, even if only for thirty minutes to allow for a break. If not, overtime should be allowed more often for such occasions. Why should a leasing agent get the GOI bonus if they already receive other monetary incentives? They don't control budgets, or work to maintain delinquency or maintenance expenses. Give employees the ability to express their individuality by NOT forcing them to wear uniforms (office staff). There can and should be a happy medium. RVP and SVP's have a tendency to micromanage to the extent that it makes it so that onsite staff are almost talking in circles. Have confidence in your onsite team and management personnel to make the best call regarding residents. They have a repertoire with them and interact with them daily.

title: If you want to gain experience...
pros: Great entry level job if you're trying to get into leasing. Commissions are great at times. Great benefits. You can grow if this is something you see yourself doing for a long time.
cons: You will be working long stretches at a time sometimes 10 days straight. And mostly weekends. Each property is different so every manager makes up their own rules. There is no type of grace period so if you're a commuter or live further from the property you might be setting yourself up. Can be overwhelming depending on the size of the property. You will be micromanaged. People can be extremely rude...which in property management it comes with the territory...but there will be days where you are completely over it.

title: Okay Company
pros: Adequate pay and bonus structure.
cons: No support from upper management. No support from team. Everyone just does their job which is good but people do the bare minimum to keep their job. Nobody works as team. Office staff does not support maintenance staff. Property Managers micro-manage maintenance staff. Company still uses hard copies of files and maintenance work orders instead of doing it on computer. Unnecessary paperwork required which just makes everything take 10 times as long.

title: MAA has a BRIGHT future! Get in where you fit in!
pros: Lots of foundation work as far as systems and platforms has already been completed. So many wise decisions have been made for the company up to this point - now it's time to reap the fruits of the labor.
cons: Still some things to address to truly be able to execute on all this good stuff MAA has to offer. If you know what ignites passion in you at work, you can find it at MAA. If you're still searching for your career personality, you may struggle a bit. But stay with it!!! MAA has so much going for it. With a TON of success to boot!!!

title: MAA does a lot right!

The company has strong core values and I LOVE the company more than any other I've worked for. They try to set the tone to make it a great place to work and live. They provide incentives to stay with the company beyond a year, great benefits at a reasonable cost, a nice amount of PTO and sick leave, hand written birthday cards, thanksgiving dinners for your family, Christmas bonuses, bonuses for meeting or exceeding benchmarks, kudos for hard work and sometimes even a phone call from the top for exceeding goals. MAA invests in its employees without reservation. I plan to stay with this company and maybe even invest in it myself. MAA isn't going anywhere anytime soon and I would recommend this company to any and everyone I know.

cons: It is pretty unsettling when you are told by a your superviser and additional higher management to intentionally keep things from HR and to keep something from additional upper management. This has happened on at least two separate occasions. There is a lot of favoritism given to maintenance. They get to get away with so many things that the office can't get away with. They have a different set of rules they have to abide by. There is favoritism to the "pretty people" If you are young and have the "cute" factor, you get more attention from management. If you are overweight and not pretty you have a black mark against you.

title: MAA is a great company that takes care of its employees and promotes from within.
pros: Great schedule and fun working environment! I love what I do and working with my team everyday.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Undervalued and overlooked
pros: In the beginning we felt recognized and as though the company had a plan for advancing their employees. Smaller groups/portfolios allowed for more relatable and personal interactions between emails employees and their supervisors.
cons: Being with the company many for several years means nothing. Constantly being pacified with false hopes and no tools to advance your career. Expected to do a lot for little to no reward.

title: Great company with continued growth
pros: Started from entry level and advanced over past 9 years. Transfers and promotions were supported. Steady growth in company leading to more opportunities and continued innovations to keep up with new technology. Lately an aggressive push on incentives have taken employment with the company over the top, especially if you live on property. The properties all vary so you can choose newer properties or old, fully staffed or not. These can lead to more of a consistent laid back preventative maintenance type property or a high stress responsive community with renovations and overtime and more learning opportunities. It’s all up to where you go and there’s always flexibility to cross over from maintenance to leasing even. Sit downs with the CEO and CFO during tours of such a big company is a rare and welcome perk. Most of their stories are ground up employees and very humble and confident leadership.
cons: Tribal knowledge can be limiting and sometimes hold back the highest potential for development so it is encouraged to go in with as much background as you can bring or to take classes in spare time. The challenges are changing every day and so you find yourself googling a lot and can hit some hard walls. You find a lot of support but also are expected to figure it out one way or another. Calling contractors can really effect your budget so in house as much as possible really can put the pressure on. Cost of living is escaping some of the wages. They are definitely fair and catching up with the times as far as base levels and I have seen alot of incentives and bonuses that help curb overall but some areas are hit so hard with inflation there needs to be consideration of location for salary. Otherwise maintaining staff may be hard as prices drive them out. Initially I had a lot of troubles with micromanagers working up in the company. As soon as I had trust to make some decisions and mistakes I started to grow a lot faster. This can be solved by moving around after open communication doesn’t work.

title: Growing Company with Some growing pains
pros: Nation wide company with many properties allowing for potential opportunities for advancement if that region values promoting from within.
cons: MAA is a business just like everything else. They are worried about the bottom line at the end of the day. There is nothing wrong with that because that is how the world works, but MAA tries to make everyone believe they are a small market company that is invested in it's employees and residents. In actuality MAA is just extremely good at selling their own brand to their employees. From the annual leadership conference to the divisional meetings they are constantly selling their brand to the managers and trying to get them to sell it to their associates. It's a successful model and would be great if the company practiced what it preached a little more in regards to how the business is run. It also seems that depending on which region or sub-region you're in could be run slightly differently. Although there is a broad set of guidelines within the company much of it is left to the determination of the SVP and RVP on how things should be handled. While this is necessary a greater focus from the home office on whether some policies fit into the MAA mission statement should be reviewed more to stay consistent as a company truly devoted to it's mission statement.

title: Caring, not caring
pros: Pros - I worked with a manager and assistant manager who knew their jobs and were good at them. They were respectful and understanding of the employees. Maintenance supervisor was quite organized and kept the turns on schedule. MAA seemed to care about the property and employees. They had good benefits and decent pay. I thought I was very happy there.
cons: Cons- maintenance technicians were very lazy and biased towards what tenants work orders they would do. Many times they would just close out the work order and never do the task. I also worked in an office with a leasing manager who thought she was the Queen. Her agreement was she got all the renewal commissions bc she sent out the letters. Yet 80% or more of the time myself and other leasing agents had to type up the leases and go over them with the tenants. There was another agent who only worked when she felt like it and the rest of the time kept her door closed and blinds pulled down. Yet nothing was ever said to her bc of her being related to the regional manager. And that leads me to my next issue. In 8 years of multi family experience, I never would live in the property I worked for so I could separate work from off time. MAA allowed me to live in a sister property with the discount. The day I took off to move, my regional manager and his boss went to my work property to announce they were selling it. When I asked them how long they had been planning that, they said all year, but yet they let me move in under the belief that I would have a discount for longer than what amounted to just 4 months. Well, while the property I worked for was for sale, they came up with a leasing trainer position of which I was referred to. My regional began to let me train up new employees in town and sent me to other states. As I made it through the interviews for this corporate trainer position (due to me having the highest leasing numbers and closing percentage in the company) I was told when the final interview would be. I arranged time out of state, as I was training people currently, so I could phone interview with them. That time came and went with no call. Once I began to ask my regional about it, he would avoid me. I feel it's because they offered the job to the other candidate that didn't fully fit the requirements and he had no desire to inform me. The other candidate openly stated on his Facebook that he wasn't that thrilled with the offer. Well, after being shunned like that, I still wanted to remain with the company. They had other openings in my town they could have transferred me to. Instead they made me interview like a non experienced lackey. Then they sent me a form letter stating how they wanted someone who understood the ideals of the company and could be a good asset. What kind of good asset are they going to find that's better at leasing than anyone in the company, who volunteered to help train new employees, who volunteered to work every rotating holiday so the employees who were married or had families could be with them. They just don't care about you when it's on the line.

title: MAA Review from a long term employee
pros: Job security, MAA very rarely ever sells a property and rarely ever fires employees. If you have a job with MAA, you could easily retire with the company after 30 years.
cons: MAA over the past several years has shown they now only care about their shareholders and what they can do to make more money. There are a few examples of this. 1. The first one is that they eliminated an annual bonus in 2019 without telling their employees, when pressed on this by several employees in my region the HR department said they thought they notified us, but they must have forgotten. 2. Renewal increases have gone up drastically. Gone are the days of getting a reasonable increase 3-4%, maybe 6-7% if you were in a very robust market. Instead they are trying to push 10% or more renewal increases and letting managers know that they should just tell the residents who complain to try and find a better deal elsewhere. I personally wouldn't be able to afford a 10% renewal increase as my annual raise was only 3%. They've begun to get this attitude of we are the biggest guys in town and people will do what we want. That strategy hasn't worked well in places like Dallas or Denver, two different markets that have struggled to maintain occupancy as residents look for a property with more reasonable expectations. 3. Their response to the corona virus has essentially been to tell residents they are still to pay their rent on time and if they are late due to work circumstances changing they will still adhere to their payment policies and process evictions as necessary. They don't care about their residents and how they might be impacted, only if they will get to collect their rent check or not. 4. If you plan to move up with MAA, there is no career support for your goals. They prefer for you not to get your CAM , NALP, or even CAMT certifications. If you want to get promoted, their expectation is for you to drop everything and do what they ask of you and if you say no then your chance for promotion is essentially zero, and since they don't want you getting certifications it makes it harder to look for jobs elsewhere. 5. The pay scale is not great whatsoever and their benefits don't make up for that. Their refusal to pay market pay has led to an increased shortage of employees. Some regions have seen such high employee turnover that employees leave before even finishing their 30 day training. 6. HR is not their to protect you, they are their solely to protect MAA. This is probably a given at majority of companies, but be aware that if you go to HR they will believe you are the problem. I've seen several employees get terminated after reporting their concerns to HR when they felt their direct manager wasn't assisting them. They were told each time that they felt it was best to part ways and that a new direction was needed. 7. RVP's, you either love them or hate them. Their isn't a middle ground. Some of this isn't the RVP's faults as they being given direction from Corporate on increasing rents, making more money, reducing expenses, etc. but because of this RVP's then tend to take it out on their Property Managers which is unfortunate. 8. Increasingly those working at the Corporate Office have continued to disregard what their property managers are telling them. Pricing Calls were supposed to be a conversation about what your concerns are, and have now instead turned into your Pricing Analyst (somebody who has never worked at a property) telling you what you need to be doing to rent apartments. Fees have been changed without consulting Property Managers and seeing what their thoughts are on how it will impact the business.

title: Houston Region Issues
pros: Opportunity to advance. Company is growing
cons: I can't speak to other markets, but the company's core values and the way the properties operate in Houston are incredibly different. One of MAA's core values is operating with integrity, but when it comes into practice this is not the case. In the Houston market employees are consistently undervalued. They seem to have the mentality that everyone is replaceable. In 2019 there was turnover of at least 8 property managers for various reasons, but most stemming from poor leadership. Many of these managers had been with the company for 5 years or more and one going back over 10 years. When an employee asks for help you are consistently asked to consult the ever growing online database of policies and procedures. If you make a judgement decision that contradicts something from this online database you are berated by your superiors for not knowing the policy. But if you ask too many questions you will be pegged as someone not able to be independent, and forfeit any chances of being promoted. In addition to their lack of employee appreciation, MAA also actively and openly employees shady business practices when it comes to their vendors. Vendors who are willing to adjust invoices to read something different than the work that was done are able to continue working for MAA. Vendors who will not employ these shady business practices will be turned away, and replaced with vendors who will. This is all done so that work can be done and coded as a capital invoice when in actuality the work being done is a regular business expense. This is done because bonuses are based on your expense budget, and GOI. Capital expenses are completely separate, and are not part of the bonus structure for the managers. This is all being done with the knowledge of senior leadership. This type of company culture only seems to continue to get worse with each year. As more pressure is put on the markets to balance occupancy and rent growth. This constant struggle is exceedingly difficult when your direct supervisor tells you to focus occupancy over rent growth, but the company COO and CEO are constantly telling you not to give up rent growth for high occupancy. Leaving MAA was one of the best decisions of my career.
